questions.question: What makes combinations more effective than throwing single punches?
questions.explanation: The key to effective combinations is the continuous rotation from left to right (and right to left). As Jordan explains: 'Every single punch links into the next one... the jab is what starts it all and that's coming from this position to this position. This bit of rotation can turn my body through nearly 180 degrees to line up my cross.' Each punch naturally flows into the next when you maintain this rotational axis.

options.text: Each punch sets up the next through continuous body rotation from left to right
You can throw punches harder when they're in a combination
Combinations look more impressive and score better points
Single punches are actually more effective than combinations

questions.question: Where does the power come from when throwing a cross?
questions.explanation: The cross gets its power from the kinetic chain: hip drop → hip rotation → upper body rotation → arm extension. Your arm is catapulted by your body rotation, not pushed by arm muscles. Tensing early actually slows the punch down.

options.text: Pushing your arm forward as hard as possible
Hip rotation that transfers through the kinetic chain to your arm
Tensing your shoulder and bicep before you punch
Leaning your body weight forward toward the target

questions.question: Your training partner says your cross is 'telegraphed' and they can see it coming. What should you check first?
questions.explanation: Telegraphing happens when you give visual cues before the punch: pulling the hand back, tensing the shoulder, or doing a 'bow and arrow' motion. The punch should initiate from the hips with the arm staying relaxed until extension. The arm follows the body, not the other way around.

options.text: Whether you're pulling your arm back or tensing your shoulder before throwing
Whether you're rotating your hips enough
Whether your cross has enough power
Whether you're looking at where you want to punch

questions.question: Which defensive technique is being demonstrated in this image?
questions.explanation: The CATCH is performed by turning your rear hand outward to meet an incoming jab with a little pressure. It's specifically effective against jabs because they carry less power. Unlike a parry which redirects the punch, the catch stops it in place. Your catch hand mirrors the opponent's punch side.

options.text: Parry - redirecting the punch to the side
Catch - meeting the jab with the rear hand turned outward
Full Block - both hands covering the face
Slip - moving the head offline

questions.question: When would you use a PARRY instead of a CATCH?
questions.explanation: The PARRY redirects punches off-course rather than stopping them. This is crucial for power shots like the cross - just turning your hand (catch) won't stop a hard cross from getting through. With a parry, you rotate slightly and tap the punch aside, taking it off course. This also leaves the opponent off-balance and open for counters. Catches work for jabs because they carry less power.

options.text: Against a jab, because jabs are faster
Against a cross, because redirecting a power shot is more effective than trying to stop it
Against hooks, because they come from the side
Against body shots, to protect the liver

questions.question: During sparring, body shots keep landing on your liver and ribs. What should you focus on to fix this?
questions.explanation: Body shot defense relies on your ELBOWS covering your liver and spleen - not your hands. Key adjustments: (1) Keep elbows tucked tight against your body, (2) Concave your stomach inward to make a smaller target, (3) Lean SLIGHTLY into incoming body shots so your elbow absorbs more impact. If elbows are flared out, you have to move them further to block. Good shape = easy body defense.

options.text: Bring your hands lower to cover your body
Keep elbows tucked, concave your stomach, and lean slightly into body shots
Move back to create distance from body punches
Throw more punches to keep them on defense

questions.question: A boxer is slipping punches but keeps getting hit anyway. Looking at their technique, they're bending forward at the WAIST instead of using hip rotation. What's the main problem with this?
questions.explanation: When you bend at the waist instead of rotating your hips and using your legs, you shift your weight forward uncontrollably. This destroys your balance, makes it nearly impossible to return to guard quickly, and leaves you unable to throw effective counters. Proper slipping uses hip rotation with a slight shoulder dip while maintaining the 60% back foot weight distribution.

options.text: Their head moves too far off the centerline
They lose balance and can't counter effectively
The movement is too slow
Their guard naturally drops

questions.question: When slipping a jab from an orthodox opponent (you're also orthodox), why should you slip to the OUTSIDE (your left) rather than to the inside?
questions.explanation: When you slip a jab to the outside (your left vs an orthodox opponent), you move AWAY from their rear hand (the cross). If you slipped inside, you'd be moving directly into the path of their power punch. The same principle applies in reverse when slipping their cross - you slip to your right to avoid their follow-up jab.

options.text: Slipping outside is faster than slipping inside
Slipping outside moves you away from their power hand (the cross)
Your head travels a shorter distance when slipping outside
It's easier to see the punch when slipping outside

questions.question: What's the key difference between a ROLL and a WEAVE?
questions.explanation: The key mechanical difference is hip engagement. When rolling, you use leg bend and hip rotation while keeping your torso relatively upright. When weaving (like Mayweather), you bend more at the hips, bringing your head forward and down before coming up on the other side. Weaving covers more distance forward but requires more flexibility and timing.

options.text: A roll uses more knee bend, a weave uses more hip bend forward
A roll is faster, a weave is slower but more evasive
A roll goes left-to-right, a weave goes forward-to-back
A roll is for hooks, a weave is only for straight punches

questions.question: Look at the diagram showing two boxers. Based on the distance between them (feet almost in line, guards nearly touching), what range are they fighting at?
questions.explanation: This is mid-range. At mid-range, your feet are almost in line with your opponent's, and you throw hooks where your palms face downward. If the palm faces toward you, that's close range. If it faces outward, that's long range. Mid-range requires constant head movement and hand defenses rather than foot defenses.

options.text: Out of range - too far to land any punches
Long range - only jabs can reach
Mid range - hooks with palms facing down land effectively
Short range - shoulder to shoulder, throwing uppercuts

questions.question: Why is controlling distance (range management) considered one of the most important skills in boxing?
questions.explanation: Range management determines everything in boxing. At each range, different punches become effective - jabs at long range, hooks at mid range, uppercuts at short range. Being out of range means you're safe but can't attack. Understanding range lets you choose when to engage and with which weapons, while knowing when you're vulnerable. Both tall and short fighters need range management - taller fighters to keep opponents at distance, shorter fighters to close the gap.

options.text: It makes you look more professional in the ring
It determines which punches can land effectively and when you're safe from attack
It's only important for taller fighters who need to stay at distance
It helps you conserve energy by standing still more often

questions.question: You keep getting caught flat-footed during sparring and can't react quickly to your opponent's attacks. What should you work on?
questions.explanation: Being 'light on your feet' comes from strong feet and tendons, built through skipping, running, and practice. Transfer your weight between the balls of your feet constantly - this lets you change position quickly. The Maasai tribe can jump incredibly high using just their plantar fascia, and boxers use similar principles to stay mobile and reactive.

options.text: Bouncing - stay on the balls of your feet and build foot strength through skipping
Throw more punches to keep them on the defensive
Just stand closer so you don't need to move as much
Focus only on blocking - movement isn't that important

questions.question: Why do we transfer weight BACKWARDS (from front foot to rear foot) when throwing a lead hook?
questions.explanation: When throwing a lead hook, transferring weight backwards from front to rear foot creates centripetal force - the same principle as a hammer thrower pulling the hammer inward to whip it around faster. This 'pulling back' motion accelerates your knuckles through the target. Moving weight FORWARD (a common mistake) removes this pulling force and kills your power.

options.text: To reach further with the punch
To pull the knuckles around faster using centripetal force - like a hammer thrower pulling the hammer
To protect your chin from counter punches
To wind up for more power by loading the rear leg

questions.question: When throwing a hook to the body, which palm orientation is correct?
questions.explanation: For body hooks, the palm should face UPWARD with the wrist kinked. This allows the knuckles to dig up under the ribs (targeting the liver or spleen) for maximum damage. A flat or downward-facing palm can't achieve this angle and reduces effectiveness significantly.

options.text: Palm facing downward (knuckles up)
Palm facing upward with a kinked wrist to dig under the ribs
Palm facing your own face (thumb up)
Palm facing outward (away from body)

questions.question: You throw lead hooks but constantly feel off-balance and find yourself stumbling forward. What's the most likely cause?
questions.explanation: Falling forward on the lead hook is a SUPER common mistake caused by pushing weight toward your knuckles instead of pulling backward. This removes all power and resistance behind the punch. Think of a hammer thrower - they pull BACK to whip the hammer around. Your knuckles should whip forward while your weight stays back or transfers rearward.

options.text: Your stance is too narrow
You're transferring weight FORWARD instead of backward - moving your axis toward your knuckles
You're not turning your lead foot enough
You're throwing the hook too fast

questions.question: Your sparring partner says they can always see your jab coming. What are you most likely doing wrong?
questions.explanation: If opponents can see your jab coming, you're telegraphing it. This usually means you're either: (1) pulling your hand back before throwing, (2) contracting your bicep before the punch (creating visible tension), or (3) making a face or breathing pattern that signals the punch. The fix is the 'relaxation to tension' principle - stay completely loose until the moment of impact.

options.text: Tensing your arm or pulling your hand back before throwing
Throwing the jab too fast
Not throwing enough jabs
Standing too close to them

questions.question: Where does punching power primarily originate from?
questions.explanation: Punching power starts from the ground. By exerting force into the floor with your feet, you initiate the kinetic chain: the ground pushes back, allowing your hips to rotate, which stretches the fascia across your torso, whipping your shoulders and arm through. Your arm essentially 'snaps out by itself' from this chain reaction—the power comes from your core and legs, not from pushing with your arm muscles.

options.text: The arm muscles (biceps and triceps)
The ground, through the kinetic chain (feet → legs → hips → torso → arm)
The shoulder muscles pushing the arm forward
Tensing all upper body muscles at once

questions.question: Your punches feel 'arm-heavy' with no snap. You notice your back heel stays planted and your hips barely move. What should you fix first?
questions.explanation: The fix is rotation, starting from your back foot. Your spine is your axis of rotation—pivot on the ball of your back foot, which turns your knee, which turns your hip to face perpendicular to your opponent. This rotation should go through nearly 180 degrees (from side-on to facing forward). Keep your head still as the axis point while your body rotates around it. Without this hip rotation, you're just arm-punching and missing the entire kinetic chain.

options.text: Punch harder by tensing your arm more
Pivot on the ball of your back foot and rotate your hips to face the target
Lean your head forward to put more weight behind the punch
Throw the punch faster with more arm speed

questions.question: You notice you keep getting pushed off balance when you throw punches, especially combinations. What's most likely wrong with your stance?
questions.explanation: Balance comes from how you plant your feet. Oliver uses the analogy: 'Boxing as though your feet are stuck in mud. If your feet are stuck in mud, no matter how hard or how much power or speed you put into a punch, you're not going to fall off balance because your feet are fixed to the ground.' The key is to push backwards with your front foot and forwards with your back foot simultaneously, creating opposing forces that keep you stable.

options.text: You're not gripping the ground with your feet and creating stability between them
Your gloves are too heavy
You're throwing punches too slowly
Your arms are too long for your body

questions.question: Looking at this diagram showing a boxer with their weight too far forward - what specific problem does this create?
questions.explanation: When weight is too far forward, your head moves into danger. As Oliver explains: 'It's very easy to be front foot dominant like this, leaning over that front foot, getting your head in range where it can get smacked around.' The solution is to get your weight back while using proper rotation to still reach the same distance. Your head stays safe, but your punches can still land.

options.text: It makes your hooks weaker
Your head is in range where it can get hit, and you're easier to push off balance
Your rear hand punches become slower
It's harder to hear your coach

questions.question: Why is relaxation so important in your boxing stance and when throwing punches?
questions.explanation: Oliver explains the anatomy: 'If you didn't know, your muscles move your skeleton. When we're punching, it wouldn't be advantageous to tense my bicep because it's doing the opposing contraction - it's gonna be harder for me to extend my arm.' Tension before a punch acts like a brake. You need relaxation UNTIL the moment of impact, then you tense to create a solid connection. It's 'relaxation to tension, not tension to relaxation.'

options.text: Tension in your arms slows down your punches because contracted muscles resist the extension
Relaxation makes you look calmer to your opponent
It's not important - you should always be tense and ready
Relaxation only matters in the ring, not during training

questions.question: What's wrong with this uppercut?
questions.context: The boxer drops their arm way down and back before throwing the uppercut.
questions.explanation: Dropping your arm all the way back is a 'super common mistake' that telegraphs your punch. Your opponent sees it coming. The arm only needs to drop to about 90 degrees at the elbow - the power comes from body rotation, not from winding up your arm.

options.text: They're telegraphing the punch by winding up too much
They need to drop their arm even lower to generate more power
Their stance is too narrow for an uppercut
They should be looking at their fist to aim properly
